speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Chelsea, you are in for a rare treat tonight.  Hmm, this is the best opera, and Ben Heppner is singing the role of Tristan.

speaker: Chelsea
text: Oh, this is gonna be a whole new experience for me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Why, you've never been bored before?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear.  The car seems to have stalled. [_turns the keys, no luck_]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh great, now what?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, let's not panic.  Chelsea, if you would, please, open the glove compartment.  You will find a flashlight and a small toolkit.  Reach behind them, and hand me my cell phone.  I'm going to call the auto club.

speaker: Niles
text: By the time they get here, we'll miss the opera.

speaker: Chelsea
text: You know, my ex-boyfriend used to restore Corvettes. Maybe I can poke around and take a look.

speaker: Daphne
text: I suppose I could give you a hand.  You don't grow up with eight brothers and not learn a thing or two about engines. Or the importance of being first in the shower.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, now, ladies, Niles and I are no strangers to the automobile.  Niles, let's have a look.  I'll pop the hood.

speaker: Niles
text: That won't void the warranty, will it?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughs to cover_] That's very funny, Niles.  No cause for alarm, ladies.  Here we go. _He pulls a switch.  Behind them, the trunk (boot) pops open, demolishing his credibility beyond repair.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Apartment Martin and Roz are sitting in the apartment.  Martin is cradling a Dalmatian puppy, when Eddie runs in._

speaker: Martin
text: Ha-hey, Eddie! [_to the puppy_] This is my boy, Eddie!

speaker: Martin
text: This is my other boy, Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God!  Dad, you know very well we have no room in this house for another dog, let alone a puppy!  They chew the furniture, they-they dig like demons, and they soil the carpet!

speaker: Roz
text: The puppy's mine, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, congratulations, everybody should have one.

speaker: Roz
text: Alice just begged me for one.  Martin, thank you so much for helping me pick him out.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, are you kidding?  I had a blast!

speaker: Martin
text: Now, here's Eddie's old puppy collar, and his brush, and his first chew toy. _Roz hands the puppy to Frasier to accept them.  He immediately starts climbing up Frasier's shirt and licking his face._

speaker: Roz
text: Oh Martin, I can't believe you kept all his things.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, always thought he'd have a brother or two.  You know, you always think you're gonna have one more.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_nearly smothered_] Dad, I said you could have a fish! Roz, would you help me here, please?!

speaker: Roz
text: You know, Martin, I could use someone to help me walk him while I'm at work.  You could be like his grandfather.

speaker: Martin
text: That'd be great!  You know, he looks kind of thirsty, Roz, you might want to get him some water.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, that's a good idea.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh look, a puppy!

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah hello, Niles.  Come on in.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier.  Took me half the morning, but I finally found it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good.

speaker: Martin
text: Found what?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, a night school catalog.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, what classes you guys looking for?

speaker: Niles
text: Auto repair.

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs_] No, seriously.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, we are serious, Dad.  Niles and I felt completely helpless last night when my car broke down.

speaker: Niles
text: And I vowed never to be humiliated that way again.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I'm more than a little convinced that's why Chelsea turned me down for a second date.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sure that had nothing to do with it.  If I had to guess, I'd say it was all that blubbering at the opera that killed your chances.

speaker: Frasier
text: But it was Ben Heppner singing Tristan!

speaker: Niles
text: You'd have to be stone not to weep at his tragic end!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, hey! [_covers his ears_] Haven't seen it yet.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_opens the catalog_] Here we are: Basic Car Repair & Maintenance.  I will call the bursar at once.

speaker: Martin
text: You guys are really gonna do this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mmm-hmm.

speaker: Martin
text: Monkey around with engines, get calluses and grease under your nails?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Actually, I'm looking forward to it, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, good for you, Frasier!  I'm impressed.

speaker: Frasier
text: As the enigma we call Shakespeare once wrote, "I am a true laborer.  I earn that I eat, get that I wear.  O no man hate, envy no man's happiness."

speaker: Martin
text: You just couldn't let me enjoy it, could you? _FADE TO:  Scene Three - Roz's Apartment Roz comes home from work.  Martin is sitting with the puppy._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Grandpa.  How was the little critter today?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, terrific.  Ate all his chow - least he did after I added some water, giving it a kind of gravy texture.  Then we took a walk in the park.  They're only young once, Roz.  Savor the days. _Roz sits on the couch.  The puppy jumps onto her lap and stands up, licking her face._

speaker: Roz
text: You had a good day today, didn't you?  Didn't you?  Yes?

speaker: Martin
text: Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: You shouldn't play with him that way.

speaker: Roz
text: Why not?

speaker: Martin
text: If you let him stand on you, it makes him think he's dominant, and you're below him in the pack.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I didn't know that. [_puts him down, and he sits on the couch_]

speaker: Martin
text: Don't worry, it's a common mistake.  That's why I'm here. So, uh, you're just gonna let him sit on the couch like that?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  He looks cute.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, all right, but you know if you let him sit on the furniture, he's gonna think he's equal to you.

speaker: Roz
text: I've seen Eddie sitting on the furniture.

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs_] You don't really want to compare this puppy to Eddie, now do you?

speaker: Roz
text: All I'm saying is Eddie breaks those rules.

speaker: Martin
text: And Hank Aaron held his bat all wrong!  The great ones have always broken the rules.  But first they learn the fundamentals, and that's what I'm trying to teach Frankie.

speaker: Roz
text: "Frankie?"  You named my dog?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, he's got to have a name to respond to, and you were taking a long time coming up with one.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, Alice picked one last night: Ariel, from _The Little Mermaid._

speaker: Martin
text: [_appalled_] Ariel?  That's a girl's name!

speaker: Roz
text: I know, but she likes it, so we're going to stick with it.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, all right. [_under his breath_] Shouldn't screw the dog up too much.

speaker: Roz
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing, I-I'd better be heading home.

speaker: Roz
text: Wait, I'll walk with you.  I'm gonna take Ariel with me to pick up Alice at preschool. [_looks around_] Where'd he go?

speaker: Martin
text: He's in the bedroom.

speaker: Roz
text: Ariel!  Ariel!  Oh shoot, I'm gonna be late.  Ariel!

speaker: Martin
text: [_not raising his voice_] Frankie? _The puppy runs out of the bedroom and stops next to Martin's foot. He smiles._

speaker: Roz
text: Not one word.  _They leave together.  FADE TO:_  **GENTLEMEN, MEET YOUR ENGINES**  _Scene Four - Classroom Frasier and Niles are sitting in desks in the front row, looking the very picture of model students - backs straight, collars buttoned, eager smiles, and shiny new notebooks._

speaker: Niles
text: Feels good to be back in class again, doesn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's fantastic.  You know, I'm almost jealous of whoever gets to sit here during the day and make learning his full-time occupation.

speaker: Niles
text: [_looks over_] Well, judging from the carving on your desk, it looks like his name is "Ozzy."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking down_] Yes, and apparently he "rules."

speaker: Randy
text: All right, everybody, my name is Randy, and if you'll take your seats we'll get started.

speaker: Niles
text: We're already seated, Randy!

speaker: Randy
text: Welcome to Basic Car Repair & Maintenance.  This is gonna be a real simple, low-stress class for people who don't know much about cars.

speaker: Randy
text: Yeah?

speaker: Shirley
text: What if you don't know anything about cars - I mean, absolutely nothing?

speaker: Randy
text: Well, then-

speaker: Frasier
text: [_getting up_] Randy, if I may? [_turns and addresses the room_] On behalf of the class, I would like to say that I-I feel that we're all a bit anxious.  But with Randy as our driver, and Desire as our gasoline, we will complete this journey together.  To paraphrase a famous little engine, "I think we can."

speaker: Randy
text: Thank you. [_Frasier sits back down_] Anyway, let's, uh, start with the basics.  A car burns gasoline to create small, carefully-timed explosions, whose energy is converted by the engine into forward motion. [_turns to the chalkboard_] I'll show you how that happens.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, the engine is just like the timpani, the way it drives the orchestra forward.

speaker: Niles
text: [_also whispering_] The conductor drives the orchestra, not the timpani.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, the conductor _guides_ the orchestra.  He's more like the steering wheel.  The actual driving forward - the driving forward is actually executed by the percussion section.

speaker: Niles
text: Seems like someone needs to take a class in orchestra rather than automobiles.

speaker: Randy
text: ...which links the crankshaft to the camshaft, so that the valves are in sync with the pistons.

speaker: Shirley
text: Oh! _Frasier and Niles exchange a glance of mingled incomprehension and panic._

speaker: Randy
text: Now, as you can imagine, tolerance is very important in every component...

speaker: Niles
text: [_as Randy continues; whispering_] What's a camshaft?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_whispering_] I don't know, you were talking!

speaker: Niles
text: [_looks through his textbook_] Oh, here it is. [_reads_] "The camshaft is a system that opens and closes the valves." Oh right, so it's this thing here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, right, right!

speaker: Niles
text: Whew!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good God!

speaker: Niles
text: That was close.  We almost got behind.

speaker: Frasier
text: We must not let that happen again.

speaker: Niles
text: Agreed.

speaker: Randy
text: ...And if you only take one thing away from this course, that should be it! _Frasier and Niles exchange another look and start writing madly in their books._

speaker: Randy
text: OK, moving on! _DISSOLVE TO:  Scene Five - Classroom Later that night, the students are working on sample engines sitting on the table.  Niles is the only one in the room wearing safety goggles._

speaker: Randy
text: So, if you're finished changing spark plugs, you're free to leave, and I'll see you next week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, it's down to us and Shirley!

speaker: Shirley
text: [_ecstatic_] I did it!  I did it!  Whoo!

speaker: Randy
text: Good job, Shirley.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right, perseverance, Frasier.  We'll get this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, right.  Oh, would you take off those stupid goggles?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm sorry, it's for safety.

speaker: Frasier
text: Nobody else wore them!

speaker: Niles
text: No one else wore them in gym class either, but then Tommy Fritz scratched his cornea, and then they were mandatory!

speaker: Frasier
text: Give me that wrench.  Give me that wrench!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm telling you, I'm telling you, they are too tight!

speaker: Frasier
text: Here, I'll just try to loosen it up.

speaker: Randy
text: Whoa, whoa!  Remember, uh, spark plugs come out with a simple twist-and-pull.  Twist-and-pull.  Give it a try.

speaker: Randy
text: OK, uh, that's called stripping it.

speaker: Niles
text: Good job, Frasier!  Here, let me strip one.

speaker: Randy
text: No, no, stripping it means breaking it.  Uh, watch me.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you... twist, and then pull.  You see, I was twisting and pulling simultaneously, as per your instructions: "twist-_and_ - pull."

speaker: Niles
text: In the future, the phrase "twist, _then_ pull" might help.

speaker: Randy
text: Look fellas, maybe that's enough for one night.  But, uh, why don't you come in a little early next week and I'll try to get you caught up to everyone else.  I've got a feeling you guys are gonna be my special project. _He leaves.  Frasier and Niles regard each other with the shocked horror of patients who have just been diagnosed with some strange disease that is not only fatal, but was also thought to have disappeared long ago._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier... we have to come in for tutoring.  We've become remedial students!

speaker: Frasier
text: I know!  It's humiliating!

speaker: Niles
text: I thought we signed up for this class to avoid humiliation!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I guess we're just gonna have to roll up our shirtsleeves and see it through for the next eight weeks.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course we will.

speaker: Frasier
text: Although...

speaker: Niles
text: I'm listening.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do we actually accomplish by learning to change our own spark plugs?  Oh yes, of course we acquire a new skill, but aren't we taking a job away from a qualified mechanic?

speaker: Niles
text: Someone who may have a family to support.  Not to mention all the merchants who dispend on his disposable income for their livelihood!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, the human toll begins to mount!

speaker: Niles
text: Society decays!

speaker: Frasier
text: Not if I have anything to say about it!  Niles, I'm quitting! If you care one jot about civilization, you'll quit too.

speaker: Niles
text: Our duty is clear.  Do we have time for gelatos?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think so, yes.  _They leave.  FADE TO:  Scene Six - Apartment Frasier and Niles arrive home.  Daphne comes out._

speaker: Daphne
text: There's my burly mechanic.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Your ears must have been burning tonight.  I've been bragging about you on the phone to my mum. [_kisses him_] I know I said you didn't have to take this auto class, but I rather like the idea of my man being able to rescue me by the roadside.

speaker: Niles
text: You do?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah.  It just shows me how much you care. [_kisses him again_]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, um, next week we're flushing radiators.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Mr. Goodwrench.  Recognize this?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's your grandpa's old toolbox.  He gave it to me when I was eighteen.  I think you're ready for it now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!  Well, thanks Dad, but, uh...

speaker: Martin
text: I know it sounds kind of corny, but it meant a lot to me when my father gave that to me.  Every time I use it I'd think of him.  Maybe every time you use it in class, you'll think of your old man and how proud he is.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, Dad, I don't know what to say.

speaker: Martin
text: Maybe someday you'll pass it on to your son.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, first maybe I'll remove the topless playing cards. [_does so_]

speaker: Martin
text: Your grandpa loved the nudies.  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **THE COASTERS**  _Scene Seven -- Cafe Nervosa Frasier and Niles are at a table, poring hard over their textbooks. Roz comes in, talking on her cell phone._

speaker: Roz
text: Yes Martin, I'll be home in time to feed the puppy.  I said I would be home!  OK, bye-bye. [_hangs up_] Your dad is driving me nuts about this dog!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, do you mind?  We're trying to study.

speaker: Roz
text: Wow, reminds me of college.  Staying up all night before a big exam and wishing I'd studied instead.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, as much as we'd love to relive those four months with you, our class begins shortly.  We're trying to learn last week's material.

speaker: Niles
text: [_closes his book_] Oh Frasier, it's useless, it's pointless, it's boring, and really, who cares?

speaker: Roz
text: Wow, it sounds like you guys should just quit.

speaker: Frasier
text: If only we could, Roz.  I, it's just that Dad and Daphne are so proud of us, we can't let them down.  They already bought mahogany frames so they could showcase our certificates of completion.

speaker: Roz
text: So complete it!  I mean, it doesn't mean you have to ace it. Just sit there and nod your head a few times, and you're home free.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you suggesting we... coast?

speaker: Frasier
text: We have never walked the back alleys of underachievement before.

speaker: Niles
text: Dare we? _They exchange a cunning look.  Frasier smiles and flips his book shut. Niles does the same._

speaker: Niles
text: Ho! [_laughs_] I felt a chill! _FADE TO:  Scene Eight - Apartment Martin is playing with Frankie/Ariel, wrestling with a sock. Eddie sits nearby._

speaker: Martin
text: Come on, Eddie, get in on this! [_Eddie stares_] Oh, what? You're too grown up for the sock game?

speaker: Martin
text: Come in!

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Martin- [_sees the puppy_] What the hell is going on?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you were late, so I brought Frankie here.

speaker: Roz
text: His name is Ariel, and I was fifteen minutes late!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that's almost two hours in doggie minutes!  Plus you didn't put the top back on his worm medicine, plus the water in his dish got dusty.  You know, Roz, I don't think the set- up's working out too well.

speaker: Roz
text: I'll say!

speaker: Martin
text: So I was thinking it might be best if he lived here with me for a while.

speaker: Roz
text: What?!

speaker: Martin
text: Just until he grows up a little bit.  You know, they need a lot of attention at this age.

speaker: Roz
text: I asked you to help me, Martin, not take over.  You're acting like my mother!

speaker: Martin
text: [_to the puppy_] See how she talks to me?  After all I've done for her, and this is the thanks I get!

speaker: Roz
text: Give him to me!

speaker: Martin
text: Roz, I don't think you're in the right frame of mind.

speaker: Roz
text: Give him to me.

speaker: Martin
text: No!

speaker: Roz
text: [_picks up Eddie_] Well, I'm leaving here with a dog, one way or another.

speaker: Martin
text: You wouldn't.

speaker: Roz
text: [_heading for the door_] Try me.

speaker: Martin
text: No, wait! _She stops.  They stand off, like negotiators in the middle of a hostage swap._

speaker: Martin
text: You first. _Roz puts Eddie down.  Martin gives her the puppy.  She lifts him to her face and he starts licking it._

speaker: Martin
text: You're not holding him right.

speaker: Roz
text: Damn it, Martin, just because I'm not raising him your way doesn't mean I'm raising him the wrong way, so butt out.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.  Can I at least come and visit him once in a while?

speaker: Roz
text: You think you can do it without criticizing me?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I promise.

speaker: Roz
text: OK.  You can come visit.

speaker: Martin
text: Bye, Frankie.

speaker: Roz
text: Hmm?

speaker: Martin
text: [_grudging_] Ariel.

speaker: Roz
text: See you later, Martin.  _Roz leaves.  Martin settles back in his Armchair.  Eddie jumps onto his lap and grabs the sock._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, there's my boy!  Yes, yeah, come on, OK...  _They start to sock-wrestle.  FADE TO:  Scene Nine - Classroom Randy is lecturing.  Frasier and Niles are now sitting in the back row, looking the picture of coasters - slouched lazily, doodling with their pencils, and grinning with "the bored, cocky air of athletes in math class." - (The phrase is Joe Keenan's, from his novel "Putting on the Ritz")_

speaker: Randy
text: Uh, the brake pedal feels a little mushy.  What is the possible cause?

speaker: Randy
text: Uh, let's get someone new this time.  How about Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Randy
text: What would cause a mushy feeling in the brakes?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know.

speaker: Randy
text: Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, mush?

speaker: Shirley
text: It's caused by a leak in the brake line!

speaker: Randy
text: Good, Shirley, did everybody hear that?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_aside to Niles_] Her voice was kind of muffled, what with her lips being pressed up against Randy's butt.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah!

speaker: Randy
text: Guys, this is the last time I'm gonna tell you, keep it down, OK?  A leak in the brake line is, uh, certainly a possible cause.

speaker: Randy
text: Ah, another cause for it might be the wheel sill.  If the caps are brittle and cracked, uh, you can develop a leak there or two.  Either case, the hydraulics... [_Frasier and Niles are still giggling_] Is that a funny note there?  I enjoy funny things.  Why don't I share it with the class?

speaker: Randy
text: Does anybody here read French?

speaker: Randy
text: Anyone besides Frasier?

speaker: Randy
text: Let me see you guys out in the hall.

speaker: Randy
text: And bring your books and tools.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh-ho, we're in trouble now.

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughing_] We're not in trouble, we _are_ trouble. _Out in the hall, however, as soon as they close the door behind them, Frasier and Niles are immediately contrite._

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, please don't throw us out!

speaker: Niles
text: We'll shut up, we promise!

speaker: Randy
text: You've promised that four times tonight.  Sorry, you're gone.

speaker: Frasier
text: But what are we gonna tell our dad?

speaker: Niles
text: And my girlfriend?

speaker: Randy
text: Maybe you should have thought of that before you started goofing off.

speaker: Niles
text: OK.  So, uh, how's this work, Randy?  You-you mail us our certificates of completion, or what?

speaker: Randy
text: [_goes along_] Yeah.  Um, let me go get a pen and paper for your addresses.

speaker: Frasier
text: All-righty. _Randy goes back in the classroom and shuts the door, even as Frasier pulls a pen out of his briefcase.  They wait for a few seconds, then Niles tries the door.  It's securely locked._

speaker: Niles
text: He's not coming back. _FADE TO:  Scene Ten - Counter Frasier and Niles are both resting on a counter, with two cups of coffee._

speaker: Niles
text: Not only did we stink at Auto class, we stunk at coasting through Auto class.

speaker: Frasier
text: We became back-row hooligans, Niles.  The very students we hated back in school.

speaker: Niles
text: I always thought they were just mean.  Now I realize they were simply acting out of frustration.

speaker: Frasier
text: So when Billy Kreizel tried to stuff you into your locker after math class, he wasn't really mad at you.  He was mad at Pythagoras.

speaker: Niles
text: Which is ironic, because a simple volume equation would have shown him I couldn't fit.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, we never should have lied to Dad and Daphne.  If we wanted to quit, we should have just quit.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, it would have saved us a lot of embarrassment. Well, that's the lesson here: never deny your true nature.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's right: honesty. _The camera widens to show them standing below a sign that says "COOL COPY."  A clerk comes back with a phony night-school certificate._

speaker: Clerk
text: This certificate look official enough?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think you finally got it.

speaker: Niles
text: Two, please.
